Question: A small wooden block has a cylindrical hole drilled through it from the front to the back.
The block measures 3cm × 3cm × 3cm, and the cylindrical hole has a diameter of 1cm.
The center of the hole is positioned exactly in the middle of the front face.
Draw or describe the top view, front view, and side view of this object in orthographic projection.

In which view(s) will the hole be visible as a complete circle? In which view(s) will the hole appear as a rectangle? 

 Solution:

The center of the hole is exactly in the middle of the front face.
I need to figure out how this hole looks in different orthographic views: top, front, and side.
First, I should recall what orthographic projection is.
From what I remember, orthographic projection is a method of creating two-dimensional representations of three-dimensional objects.
It's like projecting the object along a line (usually the x, y, or z-axis) onto a plane.
So, for each view, I need to imagine looking at the object from that direction.
Let's start with the top view.
The top view is looking down from the top, so I'm projecting the object onto the horizontal plane.

So, from the top, the hole would appear as a circle because it's a circular cylinder.

So, actually, the hole would appear as a vertical line in the top view.
But since the hole is a circle, when viewed from the top, it should still be a circle, right? Because the circular cross-section would be visible from above.
Wait, no, that's not right.
If the hole is vertical, then in the top view, which is horizontal, the hole would project as a line.
But the hole is a circle, so perhaps it's a circle in the top view.
Hmm, I'm confused.

The hole is cylindrical, so its cross-section in any plane perpendicular to its length is a circle.

Because when you look from the top, the circular cross-section is what you see.
So, the top view would show a circle.
Next, the front view.
The front view is looking along the positive x-axis, so the hole is drilled from the front face.

The side view is looking along the positive y-axis.
Since the hole is drilled from front to back, which is along the z-axis, the side view would show the hole as a vertical line.
